instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used on evaluating the behavior of spoilage microbiota and inoculated Salmonella enterica on chicken liver?
Output: Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrum was used in this study to evaluate the behavior of spoilage microbiota and inoculated Salmonella enterica on chicken liver.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used on evaluating the behavior of spoilage microbiota and inoculated Salmonella enterica on chicken liver?
Output: Feature selection based on extra-trees algorithm and support vector machine (SVM) regression analysis were used for evaluating the behavior of spoilage microbiota and inoculated Salmonella enterica on chicken liver.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the developed models in estimating different spoilage microbial groups on chicken liver?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the developed models in estimating different spoilage microbial groups on chicken liver was the root mean square error (RMSE). The RMSE measures the average difference between the predicted and observed values, providing an indication of how well the model's predictions match the actual data.

instruction: What machine learning techniques were used in the developed workflow for the quantitative estimation of different spoilage microbial groups on chicken liver using FTIR spectral analysis?
Output: The machine learning techniques used in the developed workflow for the quantitative estimation of different spoilage microbial groups on chicken liver using FTIR spectral analysis were the extra-trees algorithm and support vector machine (SVM) regression analysis.

instruction: Can Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for assessing the microbiological quality of chicken liver, based on the findings of the past study?
Output: Yes. Based on the findings of the study, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for assessing the microbiological quality of chicken liver. The past study explored the feasibility of using FTIR to evaluate the behavior of spoilage microbiota and inoculated Salmonella enterica on chicken liver. The developed FTIR spectral analysis workflow, which included data normalization, feature selection, and support vector machine regression analysis, showed promising results in estimating the different spoilage microbial groups. The performance of the models developed using FTIR was evaluated in terms of root mean square error (RMSE), correlation coefficient (R-2), bias (B-f), and accuracy (A(f)) factors. The results demonstrated that the proposed models exhibited good accuracy and precision in predicting the microbial counts of various microorganisms on chicken liver samples. Therefore, FTIR technology, in combination with the proposed spectral analysis workflow, can be considered a superior method for assessing the microbiological quality of chicken liver compared to traditional methods.
